dk.safl.beanstalkc
Class Beanstalkc

java.lang.Object
  dk.safl.beanstalkc.Beanstalkc

public class Beanstalkc
extends java.lang.Object

A beanstalkd client. Based on: https://github.com/kr/beanstalkd/blob/master/doc/protocol.txt TODO: - verify that int is a proper datatype for ttr, delay and priority. Errors produce exceptions. Methods which can either succeed or produce an error returns void. It seems weird to have functions which will either always return true or produce an exception. With such method the return value is never used. Therefore they simply either execute with or without raising an exception.

put

public long put(byte[] data,
                long priority,
                int delay,
                int ttr)
         throws java.io.IOException,
                BeanstalkcException
Create and insert a job into the currently used tube (see the "use" method).

Parameters:
data - The payload of the job.
priority - Priority of the job. Smaller priority values will be scheduled before jobs with larger priorities. Do not use priorities larger 2^32-1
delay - The number of seconds to wait before putting the job in the ready queue. The job will be in the "delayed" state during this time.
ttr - Time to run, the number of seconds to allow a worker to run this job. The time is counted from the moment a worker reserves the job. If the worker does not delete, release, or bury the job within ttr seconds, the job will time out and the server will release the job. The minimum ttr is 1. If the client sends 0, the server will silently increase the ttr to 1.
Returns:
Id of the job.
Throws:
BeanstalkcException
java.io.IOException

         throws java.io.IOException,

Throws:

use

public void use(java.lang.String tube)
         throws java.io.IOException,
                BeanstalkcException
The "use" command is for producers. Subsequent "put" commands will put jobs into the tube specified by this command. If no use command has been issued, jobs will be put into the tube named "default".

Parameters:
tube - Name of tube. If the tube does not exist, it will be created. The name must no greater than 200 bytes.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException

reserve

public Job reserve(int timeout)
            throws java.io.IOException,
                   BeanstalkcException
Get a job and exclusive access to it. If no job is available to be reserved, beanstalkd will wait to send a response until one becomes available. Once a job is reserved for the client, the client has limited time to run (TTR) before the job times out. When the job times out, the server will put the job back into the ready queue. Both the TTR and the actual time left can be found in response to the stats-job command. During the TTR of a reserved job, the last second is kept by the server as a safety margin, during which the client will not be made to wait for another job. If the client issues a reserve command during the safety margin, or if the safety margin arrives while the client is waiting on a reserve command the call will throw BeanstalkcExption with the message "DEADLINE_SOON".

Parameters:
timeout - A timeout value of 0 will result in a reserve call to immediately return either a job a throw a BeanstalkcException with the message "TIMED_OUT". A positive value of timeout will limit the amount of time the client will block on the reserve request until a job becomes available.
Returns:
Job
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException

delete

public void delete(long jobId)
            throws java.io.IOException,
                   BeanstalkcException
Removes a job from the server entirely. It is normally used by the client when the job has successfully run to completion. A client can only delete jobs that it has reserved, jobs in state ready, and jobs in state buried.

Parameters:
jobId - Id of the job to remove.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException

delete

public void delete(Job job)
            throws java.io.IOException,
                   BeanstalkcException
Parameters:
job - Job instance which the caller wishes to delete.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException
See Also:
delete(long)

release

public void release(long jobId,
                    long priority,
                    int delay)
             throws java.io.IOException,
                    BeanstalkcException
Put a reserved job back into the ready queue (and marks its state as "ready") to be run by any client. It is normally used when the job fails because of a transitory error.

Parameters:
jobId - Is the job id to release.
priority - Is a new priority to assign to the job.
delay - Number of seconds to wait before putting the job in the ready queue. The job will be in the "delayed" state during this time.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException

             throws java.io.IOException,
                    BeanstalkcException

java.io.IOException

bury

public void bury(long jobId,
                 long priority)
          throws java.io.IOException,
                 BeanstalkcException
Put a job into the "buried" state. Buried jobs are put into a FIFO linked list and will not be touched by the server again until a client kicks them with the "kick" command.

Parameters:
jobId - Id of the job to bury.
priority - A new priority to assign to the job.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException

bury

public void bury(long jobId)
          throws java.io.IOException,
                 BeanstalkcException
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException
See Also:
bury(long, long)

watch

public int watch(java.lang.String tube)
          throws java.io.IOException,
                 BeanstalkcException
Add the named tube to the watch list for the current connection. A reserve command will take a job from any of the tubes in the watch list. For each new connection, the watch list initially consists of one tube, named "default".

Parameters:
tube - Name of the tube to watch, the name can be no longer than 200 bytes. The tube will be created if it does not already exist.
Returns:
The number of tubes currently in the watch list.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException

           throws java.io.IOException,
                  BeanstalkcException
Remove the named tube from the watch list for the current connection.

Parameters:
tube -
Returns:
The number of tubes currently in the watch list.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException

kick

public int kick(int bound)
         throws java.io.IOException,
                BeanstalkcException
Move buried job(s) into the ready queue. kick only applies to the currently used tube. - If there are any buried jobs, it will only kick buried jobs. - Otherwise it will kick delayed jobs.

Parameters:
bound - The upper bound on the number of jobs to kick. The server will kick no more than bound jobs.
Returns:
The number of jobs actually kicked.
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException

touch

public void touch(long jobId)
           throws java.io.IOException,
                  BeanstalkcException
Request more time to work on a job. This is useful for jobs that potentially take a long time, but you still want the benefits of a TTR pulling a job away from an unresponsive worker. A worker may periodically tell the server that it's still alive and processing a job (e.g. it may do this on DEADLINE_SOON).

Parameters:
jobId -
Throws:
java.io.IOException
BeanstalkcException
